author: By Charlie Brennan
title: While the East bakes, Colorado digs out from a late snowstorm.
description: As millions of people in the Northeast faced weekend temperatures that may near triple digits, the situation was far different in the Mountain West: the Denver metropolitan area was hit with a wet and heavy late-spring snowfall.
content: As millions of people in the Northeast faced weekend temperatures that may near triple digits, the situation was far different in the Mountain West: the Denver metropolitan area was hit with a wet and heavy late-spring snowfall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Rejecting ‘Love Letters’ to North Korea, Biden Offers Carrots and Sticks Instead
description: President Biden said he would consider expanding joint exercises with South Korea’s military that were scaled back during the Trump administration.
content: SEOUL — Love letters are out. Military exercises are back. In his first visit to South Korea since taking office, President Biden restored America’s strategy toward the Korean Peninsula to the traditional approach that prevailed before his predecessor upended generations of relations by romancing North Korea’s dictator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Australia’s New Leader Faces Peril of Winning as ‘Not the Other Guy’
description: Like Biden before him, Anthony Albanese enters office more on the back of disgust at the conservative incumbent than enthusiasm for his leadership.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — The incumbent prime minister, Scott Morrison, pushed Australia to the right and called himself “a bit of a bulldozer.” His Labor challenger, Anthony Albanese, ran as a modest Mr. Fix-It, promising to seek “renewal, not revolution.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Kylian Mbappé Will Stay at P.S.G., Rejecting Real Madrid
description: The battle to sign the world’s best young player produced dueling offers worth more than $200 million. Mbappé picked the one that will keep him in Paris.
content: Paris St.-Germain has persuaded Kylian Mbappé to sign a new contract, one of the richest in soccer history, that will keep the French striker at the club for the next three years while he pursues a second consecutive World Cup with France and attempts to end the club’s string of failures in the Champions League.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: When a Perfect Night Out Means Singing ‘Thong Song’ for Strangers
description: Whether they prefer a kitschy ambience or more of a dive, New Yorkers looking to do karaoke for a crowd have plenty of options.
content: This story is part of an occasional series exploring nightlife in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Brooke
title: The Other Affair in ‘Conversations With Friends’
description: In the Hulu adaptation of Sally Rooney’s novel, a large and tasteful home becomes an object of infatuation.
content: “I was a big fan of seeing the insides of other people’s houses, especially people who were slightly famous like Melissa,” Frances, the narrator of Sally Rooney’s “Conversations With Friends,” says early on in the novel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: She Was Told Surgery Would Cost About $1,300. Then the Bill Came: $229,000.
description: The Colorado Supreme Court ruled that Lisa French had never agreed to pay the full price when she signed service agreements with a hospital.
content: When Lisa Melody French needed back surgery after a car accident, she went to a hospital near her home outside Denver, which reviewed her insurance information and told her she would be personally responsible for paying about $1,337.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Fun, but With Structure
description: When socializing is stressful, rule-bound role-playing games can offer some relief.
content: Growing up in the 1980s, I knew there were kids like those on “Stranger Things,” which returns Friday for its fourth season, who spent their after-school hours playing Dungeons & Dragons. I was not one of them; I played with Barbies. I figured what I was doing with dolls — acting out scenes involving homework, school dances and what happened last weekend at the plastic pool — was a far cry from the secretive world of the D&D table, with its arcane mythos and complicated rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Alvar
title: ‘Washed Out, White Out’: A Gentrification Story
description: The Dominican American family at the center of this debut lives in a New York City neighborhood threatened by luxury condominiums and high-rises.
content: Near the beginning of “Neruda on the Park,” Cleyvis Natera’s earnest, provocative debut novel, a brutal attack makes the news. The body of 7-year-old José García is found naked and “shot numerous times, the reporter said, left with a message carved into his back: Go Home.” The crime shakes Nothar Park, a fictional Dominican enclave in Upper Manhattan. But “the loss wasn’t singular, Dominican,” Natera writes. To a vigil for the young victim, “immigrants had come from every borough to say we’re all neighbors, this is our loss, too.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Long Covid Is Dangerous. The Fear of It Still Shouldn’t Rule Your Life.
description: Why a reasonable fear of chronic illness isn’t a case against normal living.
content: Since the initial Omicron wave receded and inflation replaced Covid-19 in the headlines, the debate over reopening has largely been settled in favor of the reopeners. But the debate over the wisdom of reopening and unmasking hasn’t gone away. As Covid cases rise again, there is still a vocal constituency that thinks too much normalcy is a public health mistake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: ‘A form of hope’: As air-raid sirens sound, a Lviv orchestra opens a summer festival with Mozart’s Requiem.
description: Even as the Lviv Philharmonic theater became a wartime hub for humanitarian supplies, it has remained a home for musicians and choirs.
content: The audience members took their seats among boxes of medicine, first-aid kits and intravenous tubes. The orchestra was missing four men who are now fighting on the war’s front lines. A handful of guest singers who had fled bombings and bloodshed stood onstage with the choir.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: In Australia, skipping the polls comes with a fine.
description: Compulsory voting is seen as forcing candidates toward the political center.
content: After Australia’s 2016 federal election, a parliamentary committee urged the country’s election commission to investigate the worryingly low voter turnout, saying the trend may signal trouble for the health of its democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Ruth Graham
title: Archbishop Bars Pelosi From Communion Over Abortion Stance
description: Archbishop Salvatore J. Cordileone, who has repeatedly confronted the House speaker over her backing of abortion rights, said her stance was a “grave evil.”
content: WASHINGTON — An ultraconservative archbishop in San Francisco said on Friday that Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California would not be permitted to receive communion in his archdiocese because of her support for abortion rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Russian forces are attempting another crossing of a river where they suffered a major blow, Ukraine’s military says.
description: The 650-mile-long Seversky Donets River originates in Russia and meanders southeast through the Donbas region before re-entering Russian territory.
content: Russia’s military prepared on Saturday to attempt another pontoon crossing of an eastern Ukrainian river that has posed a formidable barrier to its aims in the region, Ukraine’s military said, despite suffering one of its single most lethal engagements of the war in a previous attempt this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Johnny Depp and Other Pirates
description: Plundering our attention and poisoning us with lies.
content: WASHINGTON — We got a rare glimpse of the tortured soul of George W. Bush this past week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Robert J. Vlasic Dies at 96; Made a Fortune by Making Pickles Funny
description: His company took a lighthearted approach to its products, with a wisecracking stork as its mascot, and became the market leader.
content: Robert J. Vlasic, who by combining a keen sense for business with an even keener sense of humor turned his family business into the nation’s largest purveyor of pickles, gherkins, sauerkraut and a host of other briny condiments, died on May 8 at his home in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger, Andrew E. Kramer and Katrin Bennhold
title: As Biden Signs $40 Billion Aid Package for Ukraine, Calls Grow for a Cease-Fire
description: But a diplomatic resolution to the war still looks remote, amid searing questions about what would constitute a “victory” for Kyiv.
content: President Biden on Saturday signed a new $40 billion package of military and humanitarian aid for Ukraine as the country braced for a drawn-out war of attrition in its eastern regions, vowing that it would not stop fighting until all Russian forces were expelled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Anthony Albanese, the challenger, pitches ‘safe change.’
description: The opposition leader has emphasized the good that effective government can do.
content: Anthony Albanese likes to talk about his modest upbringing: He grew up in public housing in Sydney’s inner suburbs, raised by a single mother on a disability pension, and was the first in his family to go to college.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: How Jack Welch’s Reign at G.E. Gave Us Elon Musk’s Twitter Feed
description: The onetime ‘manager of the century’ paved the way for C.E.O.s to moonlight as internet trolls.
content: When Jack Welch died on March 1, 2020, tributes poured in for the longtime chief executive of General Electric, whom many revered as the greatest chief executive of all time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: A runner died in the Brooklyn Half Marathon, where organizers had warned of heat concerns.
description: It’s the first death since 2014 in the 13.1-mile run from Prospect Park to Coney Island. It was not immediately clear whether heat had played a role.
content: A runner in the RBC Brooklyn Half Marathon died on Saturday morning, and 15 other people were taken to a hospital, the Fire Department said, as potentially record-setting warm weather rolled into New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Bush Dynasty, Its Influence Fading, Pins Hopes on One Last Stand in Texas
description: George P. Bush is running to unseat the incumbent attorney general. His family, once powerful in Texas, has become an albatross as well as an asset.
content: ARGYLE, Texas — His famous name shadows George P. Bush, the only member of the dynastic political clan now in public office, as he enters the final days of an uphill campaign to unseat Texas’ attorney general.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: A Daily Aspirin Regimen May Hurt More Than Help, Experts Warn
description: Millions of Americans take aspirin to prevent a first heart attack or stroke. Now, doctors are advising against it — especially for people over 70.
content: Regina Griffith was 64 when she met her new primary care doctor for a routine checkup. He recommended a daily low-dose aspirin for heart health, she recalled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sunita Puri
title: My Patient Didn’t Die From Covid. He Died Because of It.
description: These pandemic deaths are still uncounted.
content: Lucas Callender told me that after cheating death, he had become kinder. When he was a teenager, an aggressive tumor had gnawed through part of his thigh muscle. After surgery and chemotherapy, his cancer was undetectable. He became the type of guy who would dress up as a princess for his niece’s birthday, or go to five different stores to find his dog’s favorite chew toy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert
title: With Rich Strike Out, the Filly Secret Oath Headlines the Preakness. Here’s What to Know.
description: The winner of the Kentucky Oaks and the second-place Derby finisher, Epicenter, are the top horses to watch in the 147th Preakness.
content: BALTIMORE — There are no regrets from the camp of the Kentucky Derby champion, Rich Strike, for skipping the Preakness Stakes on Saturday and forgoing a Triple Crown bid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim and Damien Cave
title: A lead for the Labor opposition, but it’s unclear whether it will reach an outright majority.
description: Early returns showed a lead for the opposition Labor Party, led by Anthony Albanese, on Saturday night, but it was unclear whether the swing away from the governing conservative coalition after nearly a decade in power would be enough to give Labor an outright majority.
content: Early returns showed a lead for the opposition Labor Party, led by Anthony Albanese, on Saturday night, but it was unclear whether the swing away from the governing conservative coalition after nearly a decade in power would be enough to give Labor an outright majority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: America Turned the Greatest Vehicle of Social Mobility Into a Debt Machine
description: Student loan debt is an albatross around the Democrats’ neck.
content: If it weren’t for all of the Black women students milling about, Bennett College in Greensboro, N.C., would be the picture of Hollywood’s idea of a small liberal arts college. The red-brick architecture anchors a manicured quad. Wide footpaths crisscross the small but tidy commons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Frank Gilbert, Preservationist in New York and Beyond, Dies at 91
description: He fought to spare Grand Central Terminal from the fate that befell Penn Station. He also helped draft a landmarks preservation law that became a model across the country.
content: Frank Gilbert, a preservationist who helped save Grand Central Terminal from being ravaged by a 55-story skyscraper and in the mid-1960s incubated New York City’s pioneering landmarks law, which undergirded preservation movements across the country, died on May 14 in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: ‘Yeah, That’s Right!’
description: Ryan McCarty and Yacob Yonas square up with an assertive Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This puzzle is a lot of fun, and I think it looks tougher than it solves, although that could be a personal wavelength issue — I made a lot of guesses but most of them were right (with a few exceptions, as always).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Vacation Reading, Unpacked
description: What do we want from the books we take with us when we travel? They can be a destination, a guide — or the tether that restores us to ourselves.
content: Now that some of us are planning to travel again, however tentatively, it’s time to consider the delicious question of vacation reading. Everyone has their own idea of what it should look like. Mine was formed at the end of a holiday weekend in middle school in the 1970s, when my friend Michelle and I pretzeled ourselves into her parents’ station wagon for the long, dull ride to New York from Massachusetts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño and Meridith Kohut
title: ‘I Want to Reset My Brain’: Female Veterans Turn to Psychedelic Therapy
description: Traumatized by war and sexual assaults, some U.S. veterans and veterans’ spouses are seeking help in a Mexican clinic that treats depression and addiction with potent hallucinogens like toad poison.
content: TIJUANA, Mexico — Plumes of incense swirled through the dimly lit living room as seven women took turns explaining what drove them to sign up for a weekend of psychedelic therapy at a villa in northern Mexico with sweeping ocean views.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Republicans Can’t Handle Losing
description: When they do, they just want to change the rules.
content: For much of the past decade, the Republican Party’s ability to win power in Washington has rested on the counter-majoritarian institutions of American politics. There is no President Donald Trump without the Electoral College, and Republicans would not have such a firm grip on the United States Senate if not for its unequal representation, which gives as much weight to the sparsely populated states of the Great Plains and the Mountain West as it does to states like New York, Illinois, California and Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Carlos Alcaraz Recently Beat Nadal and Djokovic on Clay. Could This French Open Be His?
description: Alcaraz, 19, has arrived in Paris with an unusual level of buzz and momentum for his age.
content: PARIS — When the future No. 1 Juan Carlos Ferrero was 19, he came to Roland Garros for the 1999 French Open qualifying tournament and lost in the first round.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Hochul’s Lt. Governor Pick Says He Is Afro-Latino. Some Latinos Object.
description: The three major Democrats running to become New York’s second-in-command have Latino roots, but Antonio Delgado’s claim to the heritage is being challenged.
content: In New York’s Democratic primary for lieutenant governor, one goal had unified two outsider candidates, Diana Reyna and Ana Maria Archila: vying to be the first Latino elected to statewide office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of May 16, 2022.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Braff
title: Staycation, Again?
description: Wasn’t this supposed to be the summer of big plans? Inflation, Covid-19 and instability have some travelers putting away their passports and grabbing their weekender bags: The close-to-home vacation isn’t dead yet.
content: After two years in which many travelers stayed home, 2022 was supposed to be the year of Big Travel, when trips were checked off bucket lists and the word “staycation” was retired forever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh and Pam Belluck
title: What We Know About Long Covid So Far
description: There is no universal definition of the complex condition, but clues about causes and potential treatments are beginning to emerge.
content: Among the many confounding aspects of the coronavirus is the spectrum of possible symptoms, as well as their severity and duration. Some people develop mild illness and recover quickly, with no lasting effects. But studies estimate that 10 to 30 percent of people report persistent or new medical issues months after their initial coronavirus infections — a constellation of symptoms known as long Covid. People who experience mild or moderate illness, as well as those without any underlying medical conditions, can nonetheless experience some debilitating long-term symptoms, including fatigue, shortness of breath, an erratic heart rate, headaches, dizziness, depression and problems with memory and concentration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Judge Approves N.Y. House Map, Cementing Chaos for Democrats
description: The new district lines, approved late Friday night, will create pickup opportunities for Republicans and force Democratic incumbents to run against each other.
content: A state court formally approved New York’s new congressional map late Friday, ratifying a slate of House districts drawn by a neutral expert that could pave the way for Democratic losses this fall and force some of the party’s most prominent incumbents to face off in primary matches.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Should I Read This Summer?
description: A book for “White Lotus” fans, a coming-of-age story in the Canary Islands, Werner Herzog’s debut novel (yes, it’s grim) and more.
content: Yong, who’s become well known as a Pulitzer Prize-winning writer for The Atlantic, helping to make sense of the pandemic, here turns his attention to sensory experiences throughout the animal kingdom. All creatures, from ticks to elephants, perceive the world in different ways. Yong does the best he can to put readers inside those bubbles of perception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Giuliani Meets With Jan. 6 Committee for Over 7 Hours
description: The onetime Trump lawyer was central to the former president’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election.
content: WASHINGTON — Rudolph W. Giuliani, who helped lead President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 election as his personal lawyer, sat on Friday for a lengthy interview with the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, according to people familiar with the closed-door interview.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: There Aren’t Answers in Terrorist Manifestoes. There’s Only Self-Mythologizing.
description: Reading it gives the killer the last word.
content: Last Saturday, when a white supremacist gunman killed 10 people and injured three more in a grocery store in Buffalo, he targeted Black Americans, as you may have heard by now. He even traveled to the neighborhood a day before the shooting to confirm the demographics so that he could kill as many Black people as possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: 1 Dead and Dozens Injured After 3 Tornadoes Strike Western Germany
description: Extreme weather was also felt elsewhere in Europe as heat waves threatened Spain and parts of southern France.
content: At least one person was killed and dozens were injured after three tornadoes struck western Germany, the local authorities said on Saturday, as extreme weather in Europe also threatened the continent elsewhere.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Covid Deaths Left Big Holes in the Hearts of Loved Ones. All That Grief Is Taking a Toll.
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 21, 2022.
content: “We traditionally think about people having a good death where they are in a setting where they are free of pain, their loved ones are surrounding them and their loved ones can tell them how much they meant to them.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Watching Members of the Royal Family Shake Hands and Then Shake More Hands
description: The often hectic royal tours, like this week’s by Prince Charles and Camilla, his wife, are short on substance if long on symbolism.
content: Prince Charles, who will most likely become Canada’s king, despite many polls indicating that few Canadians like the idea of him as head of state, made a speedy tour across much of the country with Camilla, his wife, this week. They arrived in St. John’s, Newfoundland and Labrador, dropped by Ottawa and finally moved onto Yellowknife in the Northwest Territories, as well as the Yellowknives Cree First Nation community in Dettah, before flying home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitt Romney
title: We Must Prepare for Putin’s Worst Weapons
description: The West needs to prepare options for how we would respond militarily and economically to a seismic shift in the global geopolitical terrain.
content: Russia’s foreign minister and its ambassador to the United States have both signaled that Russia’s debacle in Ukraine could lead to a nuclear strike. By claiming that Russia is readying its weapons, by warning of a “serious” risk of nuclear escalation and by declaring “there are few rules left,” they purposefully rattled the ultimate saber. Vladimir Putin himself has noted that he has weapons his opponents do not and that he will “use them, if needed.” Even the C.I.A. director, William Burns, has warned of the possibility that Mr. Putin could use a tactical nuclear weapon, even if there is no “practical evidence” right now to suggest it is imminent. Nevertheless, we should be prepared; the former secretary of state Henry Kissinger has argued that we should give the threat consideration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Baz Luhrmann Is Ready for Rhinestones, Cadillacs, Dr. Feelgood and a Svengali
description: In other words, yes, the director has made a movie about Elvis.
content: Baz Luhrmann dreams big.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zucchino, Yaqoob Akbary and Kiana Hayeri
title: The Taliban Pressure Women in Afghanistan to Cover Up
description: The militant group in charge of the country is aggressively enforcing a decree requiring coverings from head to toe and crushing rare public protests against the order.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Her mother begged her not to go to the protest, even as Maryam Hassanzada was on her way out the door.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Parting Ways
description: David, Karen and Paul Steinberg make the Sunday puzzle a family affair.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today’s entire puzzle is a debut — the first New York Times all-family crossword collaboration. It’s quite fitting that David Steinberg’s family are the pioneers; Mr. Steinberg’s first Times puzzle ran in 2011, when he was 14, and his parents, Karen and Paul, are also longtime puzzle enthusiasts. David has since become the puzzles and games editor for the Andrews McMeel Universal media company, and his puzzles appear in publications like The Boston Globe and The Miami Herald; he has also worked extensively on the Pre-Shortzian Puzzle Project, which has digitized most of the Times’s puzzle archive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden plans to sign Ukraine aid legislation during his trip to Asia.
description: A White House aide was bringing a physical copy of the $40 billion measure to South Korea on a commercial flight. It was passed by Congress this week.
content: SEOUL — Eager to enact legislation authorizing emergency assistance for Ukraine without delay, President Biden has directed an aide to fly to South Korea with the physical copy of the measure so he can sign it during his five-day trip to Asia, two administration officials said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: The Designer Turning Two Used T-Shirts Into High Fashion
description: Erin Beatty, of the upcycling brand Rentrayage, explains how she handcrafts her line from discarded fabrics.
content: This article is part of a series examining Responsible Fashion, and innovative efforts to address issues facing the fashion industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: The Russian Orthodox Leader at the Core of Putin’s Ambitions
description: Patriarch Kirill I has provided spiritual cover for the invasion of Ukraine, reaping vast resources for his church in return. Now, in an extraordinary step, the E.U. is threatening him with sanctions.
content: As Russia’s invasion of Ukraine unfolded, Patriarch Kirill I, the leader of the Moscow-based Russian Orthodox Church, had an awkward Zoom meeting with Pope Francis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: What Is ‘Good Cause Eviction,’ and What Does It Mean for Renters?
description: Under current New York State law, landlords are not required to offer new leases to market-rate tenants. That could soon change.
content: New York renters are feeling the squeeze, with rents in Manhattan up 32 percent in April from the same time a year ago, according to a report, and housing courts busy as evictions resume after a pandemic moratorium. Some renters are wondering: Is there any relief? Tenant advocates say yes, pointing to a bill introduced last year in the New York State Legislature called Prohibition of Eviction Without Good Cause. But what is “good cause eviction,” and what would it mean for renters and landlords if the bill, as it stands now, becomes law?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Australia decides whether to extend conservatives’ reign.
description: Australia’s federal election is a test of whether the country of 25 million people wants to end or extend nine years of conservative government.
content: Australia’s federal election is a test of whether the country of 25 million people wants to end or extend nine years of conservative government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Shane Goldmacher
title: Perdue Had Trump. In Georgia, Kemp Had Everything Else.
description: David Perdue challenged Gov. Brian Kemp because of Donald Trump’s fury over his 2020 loss. Thoroughly outflanked and failing to gain traction, he is now staring down defeat.
content: In September 2021, former Senator David Perdue was hemming and hawing about running for governor of Georgia. Over dinner with an old friend on Sea Island, he pulled out his iPhone and showed the list of calls he’d gotten from Donald J. Trump, lobbying him to take the plunge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Boeing’s Starliner Reaches Space Station Some 2 Years After Planned Visit
description: If it returns to Earth successfully next week, the space taxi built for NASA could carry astronauts to orbit later this year.
content: A couple of years later than had been hoped, Boeing’s Starliner space taxi arrived at the International Space Station on Friday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Diamond
title: Who’s Playing Dungeons & Dragons These Days? The Usual Fans, and Then Some.
description: The role-playing game has never been more popular, and players seem to be getting more out of it than ever before.
content: Everyone’s been playing Dungeons & Dragons without you: your co-workers, Anderson Cooper, Tiffany Haddish. More than 50 million people worldwide have “interacted” with D&D since it was created in the mid-1970s, according to its publisher, and while that number also includes movies, video games, books, television and livestreams, it doesn’t factor in the number of people reached over TikTok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordan Allen
title: Kenneth Welsh, Memorable as a Villain on ‘Twin Peaks,’ Dies at 80
description: In a long career onstage (including Broadway), in movies  and on television, he ranged across genres, from sketch comedy to science fiction.
content: Kenneth Welsh, a prolific Canadian stage and screen actor who was best known for his portrayal of the murderous, unhinged villain Windom Earle on the hit early-1990s television series “Twin Peaks,” died on May 5 at his home in Sanford, Ontario. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris, John Williams and Joumana Khatib
title: Writers to Watch This Summer
description: Three authors discuss their new novels and what brought them to write about a young woman in trouble, three brothers from Staten Island and an anxious parrot.
content: Leila Mottley’s first novel, “Nightcrawling,” will be published by Knopf in early June. Days later, Mottley will turn 20.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: A Library, a Pigeon and a Cruise
description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Two Democratic Congresswomen, One Redrawn Georgia District
description: A primary for the new Seventh District, outside Atlanta, is forcing two popular incumbents, Lucy McBath and Carolyn Bourdeaux, to do battle.
content: In 2018, a Democratic gun control and racial justice activist named Lucy McBath flipped a Republican-held Georgia congressional seat that, in a different configuration, had once been held by Newt Gingrich.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: This is just the beginning. Above-normal heat is forecast for most of the U.S. this summer.
description: The Northeast, from Delaware to Maine, has the highest likelihood of being extra-hot, along with parts of the West.
content: Just as temperatures were heating up for about half of the U.S. population this week, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration issued its monthly climate trends report on Thursday. The main takeaway? Prepare for a scorcher of a summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Prime Minister Scott Morrison is urging voters to opt for what they know.
description: His tenure hasn’t always been smooth, with moments that have tested the Australian public’s faith in his leadership
content: When Scott Morrison first became Australia’s prime minister in 2018, he was so little known that when he went to shake the hand of a soccer fan, the confused man asked: “What’s your name, then?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Democracy, with a side of grilled onions.
description: In a beloved tradition, every Election Day sausages are sold near polling stations as fund-raisers for local schools, churches and community groups.
content: Grill sausages and onions until they are nicely browned. Take a slice of white bread, place sausage diagonally and top with onions. Fold. Garnish to taste.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Vander Ploeg and Mitch Smith
title: Two Killed, Dozens Injured in Rare Northern Michigan Tornado
description: The deaths were reported in a mobile home park on the outskirts of Gaylord, where crews searched the wreckage on Saturday.
content: GAYLORD, Mich. — A tornado that killed at least two people and injured dozens of others dropped out of the sky in far northern Michigan on Friday and onto a mobile home park before tearing a three-block hole through the small city of Gaylord.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch
title: H.B.C.U.s Have a Spirit All Their Own. Pop Culture Is Paying Attention.
description: Thanks to Beyoncé, Ralph Lauren and hit shows like “All American: Homecoming,” depictions of Black campus life have moved from “A Different World” to center stage.
content: The collective moment when I first saw a three-dimensional reflection of my own college experience in popular culture happened not once but twice: on the television series “A Different World,” which premiered in 1987, and in Spike Lee’s film “School Daze,” which debuted in 1988. Together, they presented a meditation on the many layers and complexities of Black campus life that I had not seen before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annaliese Griffin
title: People Say, ‘Be Positive’ When You Have Cancer. I Prefer to Complain With Friends.
description: Mutual complaint can be stabilizing.
content: One of the things that has been the most difficult for me to navigate since being diagnosed with cancer is whom to tell and how. It’s not that I’m particularly private; it’s just that I don’t want my illness to become the focal point of any relationship. Even with my oncologist I crack jokes and talk about my kids and what I’m writing as much as I ask him about nausea relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Early Voting Wins Preakness Stakes
description: He held off Epicenter to win the middle race of the Triple Crown series.
content: BALTIMORE — Let’s call it a correction in the horse racing market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Golden State Was Down Big. Then Kevon Looney Happened.
description: Looney had the best night of his career to fuel his team’s comeback from 19 points down to the Dallas Mavericks in Game 2 of the Western Conference finals.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — The day before Kevon Looney produced the best game of his professional career, he sat in a hallway at Chase Center in San Francisco, thinking about the way his role had changed since Golden State drafted him in 2015.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Photographs and Video by Shawn Hubbard
title: Forging a Bond on the Ice in East Baltimore
description: For kids in East Baltimore, ice hockey is rarely the sport of choice. The Baltimore Banners team offers a chance for young people to discover the game.
content: For kids in East Baltimore, ice hockey is rarely the sport of choice. The Baltimore Banners team offers a chance for young people to discover the game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Axel Boada
title: Scott Morrison Concedes Defeat to Labor Party in Australian Election
description: Anthony Albanese, the Labor leader, will become Australia’s next prime minister after his party’s Election Day victory.
content: Anthony Albanese, the Labor leader, will become Australia’s next prime minister after his party’s Election Day victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Network Pool
title: Biden Hails United States’ Alliance With South Korea
description: In a visit to Seoul, President Biden sought to strengthen the United States’ relationship with South Korea and also said he would be open to meeting with the leader of North Korea if he was “sincere.”
content: In a visit to Seoul, President Biden sought to strengthen the United States’ relationship with South Korea and also said he would be open to meeting with the leader of North Korea if he was “sincere.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Dear God, Even if You Don’t Exist
description: Readers react to an essay about praying to a pretend God.
content: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: May 21, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, May 21, 2022.
content: An article on Friday about the Senate’s approval of a $40 billion aid package for Ukraine misstated the status of a proposed spending bill to address the baby formula crisis. Republicans voted against it this week; they did not block it.
source.name: The New York Times
